canonical_explanation.text: Our environment consists of all living things (plants, animals, humans) and non-living things (air, water, soil, sunlight) around us. Pollution is the harmful contamination of the environment. Air pollution is caused by vehicle exhaust, factory smoke, and burning waste, leading to breathing problems and smog. Water pollution is caused by factory waste, sewage, and pesticides dumped into rivers and lakes, making water unsafe and harming aquatic life. Land pollution is caused by plastic waste, garbage, and chemical dumping, making soil infertile. We can protect the environment by following the 3Rs: Reduce (use less), Reuse (use again), and Recycle (convert waste into new products). Planting trees (afforestation), properly disposing of waste, and using biodegradable products help conserve the environment. Global warming is the gradual increase in Earth's temperature due to gases like carbon dioxide trapping heat in the atmosphere.
rules: Environment: living (biotic) and non-living (abiotic) things around us
Pollution: harmful contamination of the natural environment
Air pollution: vehicle smoke, factory fumes, burning waste → breathing problems, smog
Water pollution: factory waste, sewage, pesticides → unsafe water, harm to aquatic life
Land pollution: plastic, garbage, chemicals → infertile soil
3Rs: Reduce (use less), Reuse (use again), Recycle (make new from waste)
Biodegradable waste: breaks down naturally (food waste, paper, leaves)
Non-biodegradable waste: does not break down easily (plastic, glass, metal)
Afforestation: planting new trees to improve the environment
Global warming: Earth getting warmer due to carbon dioxide and other gases

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a cause of air pollution?
questions.explanation_correct: Smoke from vehicles and factories is a major cause of air pollution. Vehicles burn petrol and diesel, releasing harmful gases and particles into the air. Factory chimneys also release smoke and toxic fumes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Planting trees actually reduces air pollution. Cycling and drinking water do not cause air pollution. Smoke from vehicles and factories is one of the biggest causes of air pollution.

questions.question_text: Burning crackers during Diwali causes:
questions.explanation_correct: Burning crackers releases harmful smoke and chemicals into the air (air pollution) and creates very loud sounds (noise pollution). This is why many cities in India discourage excessive use of crackers during festivals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Crackers cause both air pollution (from smoke and toxic chemicals) and noise pollution (from loud sounds). They do not primarily cause water or land pollution, although the waste from crackers also litters the ground.

questions.question_text: Breathing polluted air can cause:

options.text: Breathing problems, asthma, and lung diseases

questions.explanation_correct: Breathing polluted air can cause serious health problems including breathing difficulties, asthma, coughing, and lung diseases. Delhi and many Indian cities face severe air pollution that affects people's health.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Polluted air is harmful, not beneficial. It damages the lungs and respiratory system, causing asthma, bronchitis, and other breathing problems. It does not improve health in any way.

questions.question_text: Trees help reduce air pollution by absorbing carbon dioxide and releasing oxygen.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Trees absorb carbon dioxide (a harmful gas) from the air during photosynthesis and release oxygen (which we need to breathe). They also trap dust particles on their leaves, helping clean the air.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. Trees are natural air purifiers. They absorb carbon dioxide and release oxygen through photosynthesis. This is why planting trees is one of the best ways to fight air pollution.

questions.question_text: During winter, Delhi often experiences thick smog. What causes this smog?

options.text: A combination of smoke from vehicles, factories, and crop burning mixing with fog

questions.explanation_correct: Smog in Delhi is caused by smoke and pollutants from vehicles, factories, and crop burning in nearby states mixing with cold winter fog. The cold air traps these pollutants close to the ground, creating thick, harmful smog.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Smog is a combination of smoke and fog. In Delhi, it is caused by vehicle exhaust, factory emissions, and agricultural crop burning. Rain and trees actually help reduce pollution, they do not cause it.

questions.question_text: Which of the following would help reduce air pollution in a city?

options.text: Burning more garbage in the open
Using public transport, cycling, and planting more trees

questions.explanation_correct: Using public transport reduces the number of vehicles on the road. Cycling produces no pollution. Planting trees absorbs carbon dioxide and cleans the air. Together, these actions significantly reduce air pollution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: More cars, burning garbage, and more factories all increase air pollution. Using public transport, cycling, and planting trees are the actions that help reduce air pollution in cities.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a source of air pollution?
questions.explanation_correct: Windmills do not cause air pollution. They use wind energy to generate electricity cleanly. Vehicle exhaust, factory chimneys, and burning fossil fuels all release pollutants into the air.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vehicles, factories, and burning fossil fuels all release harmful gases into the air. Windmills use clean wind energy and do not produce any air pollution. They are a source of renewable, clean energy.

questions.question_text: Which of the following causes water pollution?

options.text: Dumping factory waste and sewage into rivers

questions.explanation_correct: Dumping factory waste, sewage, and chemicals into rivers and lakes is a major cause of water pollution. This makes the water toxic for drinking and harmful for fish and other aquatic life.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Saving water, drinking clean water, and filtering water are all good practices. Dumping waste into water bodies is what causes water pollution, making the water unsafe for all living things.

questions.question_text: Polluted water can cause diseases such as:
questions.explanation_correct: Drinking or using polluted water can cause waterborne diseases like cholera, typhoid, diarrhoea, and jaundice. These diseases are caused by germs (bacteria, viruses) present in contaminated water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diabetes, broken bones, and colour blindness are not caused by water pollution. Cholera, typhoid, and diarrhoea are waterborne diseases that spread through contaminated water.

questions.question_text: Water pollution harms aquatic life because:

options.text: Fish prefer clean water and cannot survive in polluted water
Fish only live in the ocean

questions.explanation_correct: Fish and other aquatic organisms need clean water with enough dissolved oxygen to survive. Polluted water contains toxic chemicals and less oxygen, making it impossible for many aquatic creatures to survive.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fish live in various water bodies, not just the ocean, and they definitely need water. Pollution kills fish because it introduces toxins and reduces oxygen levels in the water.

questions.question_text: A factory near a village dumps its chemical waste into the river. The villagers downstream use this river water. What problems could this cause?

options.text: Villagers may get sick from waterborne diseases, and fish in the river may die
The river water will become cleaner
More fish will appear in the river

questions.explanation_correct: Factory chemicals in the river make the water toxic. Villagers using this water may develop diseases like diarrhoea, skin problems, and even cancer from long-term exposure. Fish and other aquatic life will die from the chemicals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chemical waste in rivers is extremely harmful. It does not clean the water or help fish. It causes serious health problems for people who use the water and kills aquatic life.

questions.question_text: The Ganga is one of the most polluted rivers in India. What actions can help clean it?

options.text: Stopping sewage and factory waste from entering, treating waste water before release

questions.explanation_correct: To clean the Ganga, we need to stop sewage and factory waste from being dumped into it. Waste water should be treated (cleaned) before being released into the river. The Indian government's Namami Gange programme works to clean this river.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dumping more waste, ignoring the problem, or adding chemicals would worsen pollution. The solution is to treat waste water, stop dumping, and clean the existing pollution. This requires effort from government, factories, and citizens.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a cause of water pollution?
questions.explanation_correct: Rainwater harvesting is not a cause of water pollution. It is actually a method of collecting and storing rainwater for later use, which is beneficial. Factory waste, sewage, and pesticides are all causes of water pollution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Factory waste, sewage, and pesticides all pollute water bodies. Rainwater harvesting is a conservation technique that collects clean rainwater for use, helping reduce water shortage.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a major cause of land pollution?

options.text: Plastic bags, garbage, and chemical waste

questions.explanation_correct: Plastic bags, garbage, and chemical waste are major causes of land pollution. They make the soil unhealthy, kill organisms in the soil, and make the land unusable for growing plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Planting flowers and watering plants are good for the land. Playing in parks does not pollute. Plastic waste, garbage, and chemical dumping are the causes of land pollution.

questions.question_text: What is the difference between biodegradable and non-biodegradable waste?

options.text: Biodegradable waste decomposes naturally; non-biodegradable waste does not

questions.explanation_correct: Biodegradable waste (like food scraps, paper, leaves) can be broken down by bacteria and fungi into simpler substances. Non-biodegradable waste (like plastic, glass, metal) does not decompose naturally and stays in the environment for hundreds of years.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The key difference is decomposition. Biodegradable waste breaks down naturally over time. Non-biodegradable waste does not break down and accumulates in the environment, causing long-term pollution.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is non-biodegradable?
questions.explanation_correct: A plastic bottle is non-biodegradable. Plastic does not decompose naturally and can remain in the environment for hundreds or thousands of years. This is why plastic pollution is such a serious problem.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Banana peels, paper, and dry leaves are all biodegradable - they decompose naturally. Plastic bottles are non-biodegradable and remain in the environment for a very long time.

questions.question_text: Mohan throws a plastic wrapper on the road after eating chips. What would be the better thing to do?

options.text: Put it in a dustbin for proper disposal

questions.explanation_correct: The best option is to put the wrapper in a dustbin for proper disposal. This way it can be collected and sent to a recycling facility. Throwing it on the road, in a river, or burning it all cause pollution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Throwing plastic in a river causes water pollution. Burning plastic releases toxic fumes (air pollution). Burying plastic is not good because it does not decompose. The correct action is to dispose of it in a dustbin.

questions.question_text: A farmer uses too many chemical pesticides on his crops. How can this cause land pollution?

options.text: The chemicals make crops grow better
Excess chemicals seep into the soil, killing useful organisms and making soil toxic

questions.explanation_correct: Excess chemical pesticides seep into the soil, killing earthworms and other useful soil organisms. They make the soil toxic and can also wash into nearby water bodies, causing water pollution. Over time, the soil becomes infertile.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While some pesticides are necessary, excessive use poisons the soil. The chemicals kill helpful organisms, contaminate groundwater, and reduce soil fertility. This is why organic farming is encouraged.

questions.question_text:
Which pair correctly classifies waste?
Biodegradable: vegetable peels, cotton cloth
Non-biodegradable: plastic bag, glass bottle

options.text: Only the biodegradable group is correct
Only the non-biodegradable group is correct

questions.explanation_correct: Both classifications are correct. Vegetable peels and cotton cloth are biodegradable (they decompose naturally). Plastic bags and glass bottles are non-biodegradable (they do not decompose and remain in the environment for a very long time).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vegetable peels and cotton cloth do decompose naturally (biodegradable). Plastic bags and glass bottles do not decompose (non-biodegradable). Both groupings are accurate.

questions.question_text: What do the 3Rs stand for?
questions.explanation_correct: The 3Rs stand for Reduce (use less), Reuse (use again), and Recycle (convert waste into new products). Following the 3Rs helps reduce pollution and conserve natural resources.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The 3Rs related to environmental conservation are Reduce, Reuse, and Recycle. These are simple actions that everyone can follow to protect the environment and reduce waste.

questions.question_text: Using a cloth bag instead of a plastic bag when shopping is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Using a cloth bag instead of plastic both reduces plastic waste (Reduce) and the cloth bag can be used many times (Reuse). It is a simple but powerful way to reduce plastic pollution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using a cloth bag reduces the amount of plastic waste generated (Reduce) and since the cloth bag is used again and again (Reuse), it is an example of both Reduce and Reuse.

questions.question_text: Converting old newspapers into new paper products is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Converting old newspapers into new paper products is recycling. Recycling means processing used materials to make new products. This reduces the need for raw materials and reduces waste in landfills.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reducing means using less, reusing means using the same item again, and refuse means saying no. Recycling is specifically the process of converting waste materials into new, useful products.

questions.question_text: Aarti uses an old glass jar to store spices instead of throwing it away. This is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Using an old glass jar for a new purpose (storing spices) is reusing. Instead of throwing it away, Aarti gave the jar a second life. Reusing items reduces waste and saves money.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reducing means using less, recycling means processing waste into new products, and repair means fixing broken items. Aarti is reusing the jar by finding a new use for it instead of throwing it away.

questions.question_text: Which of the following actions follows the 'Reduce' principle?

options.text: Turning off lights and fans when not in use to save electricity
Using plastic plates for every meal

questions.explanation_correct: Turning off lights and fans when not in use reduces electricity consumption. 'Reduce' means using fewer resources and producing less waste. Saving electricity also reduces the pollution caused by power plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Buying more than needed, throwing food, and using plastic plates all increase waste. Turning off unused lights and fans is a simple 'Reduce' action that saves electricity and reduces the pollution from power plants.

questions.question_text: Planting trees is an important conservation activity. Why?

options.text: Trees make the area look dirty
Trees absorb carbon dioxide, release oxygen, prevent soil erosion, and provide habitat for animals
Trees use up all the water

questions.explanation_correct: Trees provide numerous environmental benefits: they absorb carbon dioxide and release oxygen (cleaning the air), their roots hold soil in place (preventing erosion), they provide shelter and food for animals, and they help bring rainfall.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Trees are extremely beneficial, not harmful. They clean the air, prevent soil erosion, provide wildlife habitat, and help regulate the water cycle. Planting trees (afforestation) is one of the best conservation actions.

questions.question_text:
Match the 3R with the correct example:
(i) Reduce - (a) Making new bottles from old glass
(ii) Reuse - (b) Turning off tap when not in use
(iii) Recycle - (c) Using old newspaper to wrap gifts
Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation_correct: Reduce - Turning off tap (b) saves water. Reuse - Using newspaper to wrap gifts (c) gives the paper a second use. Recycle - Making new bottles from old glass (a) converts waste into new products.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reduce means using less resources (turn off tap). Reuse means using items again for a different purpose (newspaper for wrapping). Recycle means processing old materials into new products (old glass into new bottles).

questions.question_text: Global warming refers to:

options.text: The gradual increase in Earth's temperature

questions.explanation_correct: Global warming is the gradual increase in Earth's average temperature. It is mainly caused by greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide that trap heat in the atmosphere, like a blanket around the Earth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Global warming is not about the Earth getting colder, spinning faster, or the sun growing. It is the gradual warming of the Earth due to increased greenhouse gases in the atmosphere.

questions.question_text: Which gas is mainly responsible for global warming?
questions.explanation_correct: Carbon dioxide is the main gas responsible for global warming. When we burn fossil fuels (petrol, diesel, coal), cut down forests, and run factories, we release large amounts of carbon dioxide into the air, which traps heat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Oxygen and nitrogen are normal atmospheric gases. Hydrogen is not a major greenhouse gas. Carbon dioxide is the main greenhouse gas that traps heat and causes global warming.

questions.question_text: What can happen if global warming continues to increase?

options.text: Ice at the poles will melt, sea levels will rise, and weather patterns will change
The Earth will become more beautiful

questions.explanation_correct: If global warming continues, polar ice will melt, causing sea levels to rise and flooding coastal areas. Weather patterns will become more extreme, with more droughts, storms, and floods. Many animals and plants may not survive these changes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Global warming has serious consequences. Melting ice, rising seas, extreme weather, and loss of biodiversity are real threats. It will not make the Earth better or animals stronger.

questions.question_text: Which of the following actions helps fight global warming?

options.text: Planting trees, using renewable energy, and saving electricity

questions.explanation_correct: Planting trees absorbs carbon dioxide. Using renewable energy (solar, wind) reduces the need to burn fossil fuels. Saving electricity means less coal is burned in power plants. These actions all help reduce global warming.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Driving more cars, cutting trees, and burning coal all increase carbon dioxide and worsen global warming. The correct actions are planting trees, using renewable energy, and conserving electricity.

questions.question_text: Planting trees helps fight global warming because trees absorb carbon dioxide.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Trees absorb carbon dioxide during photosynthesis and store carbon. More trees means more carbon dioxide is removed from the atmosphere, which helps reduce global warming.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. Trees are excellent at absorbing carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas causing global warming. This is why afforestation is an important tool in fighting climate change.

questions.question_text: Smoke from vehicles and factories causes _____ pollution.
questions.explanation_correct: Smoke from vehicles and factories causes air pollution. The smoke contains harmful gases and particles that contaminate the air we breathe, leading to health problems.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Smoke rises into the air and pollutes it. It does not directly cause water or land pollution. Vehicle and factory smoke is one of the biggest sources of air pollution.

questions.question_text: Waste that does not decompose naturally, like plastic and glass, is called _____ waste.
questions.explanation_correct: Plastic and glass are non-biodegradable waste. They do not break down naturally by bacteria or fungi. They persist in the environment for hundreds or thousands of years, causing long-term pollution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Biodegradable, organic, and natural all refer to things that can break down naturally. Plastic and glass cannot decompose, so they are non-biodegradable waste.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: We should separate dry waste and wet waste at home.
Reason: Wet (biodegradable) waste can be composted, while dry (non-biodegradable) waste can be recycled.
Choose the correct option.

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and the reason explains the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason does not explain the assertion
The assertion is true but the reason is false

questions.explanation_correct: Both are true and the reason explains the assertion. We should separate waste because different types need different treatment. Wet waste (food scraps, leaves) can be composted to make fertiliser. Dry waste (plastic, paper, metal) can be recycled into new products.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is true (we should separate waste) and the reason is also true (different waste types need different processing). The reason explains why separation is important.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly lists the types of pollution and their causes?

options.text: Air: factory smoke; Water: sewage; Land: plastic waste
Air: sewage; Water: factory smoke; Land: noise
Air: plastic; Water: noise; Land: smoke
All types have the same causes

questions.explanation_correct: The correct associations are: Air pollution is caused by factory smoke and vehicle exhaust. Water pollution is caused by sewage and chemical waste in water bodies. Land pollution is caused by plastic and other solid waste.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Different types of pollution have different causes. Factory smoke pollutes air, sewage pollutes water, and plastic waste pollutes land. The correct pairing is in option A.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the BEST way to prevent water pollution?

options.text: Treating industrial and household waste before releasing it into water bodies

questions.explanation_correct: The best way to prevent water pollution is to treat (clean) waste water before it enters rivers and lakes. Treatment removes harmful chemicals, germs, and toxic substances, making the water safe before it is released.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Throwing garbage in rivers and building factories near them increase pollution. Using more water wastes a resource. Treating waste water before release is the most effective way to prevent water pollution.

questions.question_text: Composting kitchen waste (vegetable peels, fruit skins) to make manure is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Composting kitchen waste is an excellent example of recycling biodegradable waste. The organic waste breaks down and becomes nutrient-rich compost (manure) that can be used in gardens and farms instead of chemical fertilisers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Composting does not increase pollution or create non-biodegradable waste. It is a form of recycling where biodegradable kitchen waste is converted into useful compost for gardening.

questions.question_text: A school in Mumbai starts a 'No Plastic' campaign. Students bring steel water bottles and cloth bags. Which of the 3Rs are they following?

options.text: Reduce (less plastic used) and Reuse (cloth bags and steel bottles used repeatedly)

questions.explanation_correct: By avoiding plastic, students are reducing plastic waste (Reduce). By using cloth bags and steel bottles that can be used many times, they are reusing items (Reuse). This is a great example of following the 3Rs in daily life.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The students are following two of the 3Rs: Reduce (using less plastic) and Reuse (using the same cloth bags and steel bottles again and again). This is a practical example of environmental conservation.

questions.question_text: Which activity produces the MOST carbon dioxide?

options.text: Driving a car that burns petrol

questions.explanation_correct: Driving a car that burns petrol produces the most carbon dioxide among these options. Burning petrol (a fossil fuel) releases carbon dioxide and other harmful gases. Walking, cycling, and reading produce little or no carbon dioxide.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Walking, cycling, and reading produce little to no carbon dioxide. Burning petrol in a car engine releases large amounts of carbon dioxide. This is why walking and cycling are called 'green' transportation.

questions.question_text: Rekha's family started using a solar cooker for cooking food on sunny days. How does this help the environment?

options.text: It does not help at all
It reduces air pollution because no fuel is burned, and it uses clean solar energy

questions.explanation_correct: A solar cooker uses sunlight to cook food, so no fuel (gas, wood, coal) is burned. This means no smoke or harmful gases are produced, reducing air pollution. Solar energy is clean and renewable.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Solar cookers are excellent for the environment. They use free, clean solar energy and produce no pollution. Unlike cooking with gas, wood, or coal, they release no smoke or harmful gases.

questions.question_text: Plastic bags take only a few days to decompose in the environment.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Plastic bags take hundreds of years (some estimates say 500-1000 years) to decompose. This is why plastic pollution is such a serious problem. Plastic bags pile up in the environment, harming wildlife and soil.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is false. Plastic is non-biodegradable and can take hundreds of years to break down. Even then, it breaks into microplastics that continue to pollute. This is why reducing plastic use is so important.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the BEST way to dispose of old clothes that are still in good condition?

options.text: Donate them to someone who needs them

questions.explanation_correct: Donating old clothes to those who need them is the best option. This is reusing - giving items a second life. It reduces waste and helps people in need. Burning creates air pollution, and throwing in rivers causes water pollution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Burning causes air pollution, dumping in rivers causes water pollution, and burying wastes the clothes. Donating good clothes is the best option because it reuses them and helps others.

questions.question_text: In a village, people wash their clothes and bathe animals in a pond. Over time, the pond water becomes dirty and smelly. What type of pollution is this?
questions.explanation_correct: This is water pollution. Soap, dirt, animal waste, and other substances contaminate the pond water, making it dirty and smelly. This water becomes unsafe for drinking and harms the aquatic life in the pond.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The contamination is happening to the water body (pond), so this is water pollution. The soap, dirt, and waste are making the water dirty and unsuitable for use.

questions.question_text: Using solar panels and wind turbines instead of coal power plants helps fight global warming because:

options.text: They generate electricity without burning fossil fuels or producing carbon dioxide

questions.explanation_correct: Solar panels and wind turbines generate clean electricity without burning fossil fuels. They produce no carbon dioxide during operation. Coal power plants burn coal, releasing large amounts of carbon dioxide that causes global warming.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Solar and wind energy are clean and renewable. They do not produce carbon dioxide or other greenhouse gases. Unlike coal, which releases carbon dioxide when burned, these renewable sources help reduce global warming.

questions.question_text: What does 'afforestation' mean?

options.text: Planting new trees on a large scale

questions.explanation_correct: Afforestation means planting new trees on a large scale, especially in areas where there were no forests before. It helps fight air pollution, prevents soil erosion, provides animal habitats, and combats global warming.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cutting down trees is deforestation (the opposite). Burning forests is extremely harmful. Afforestation specifically means planting trees in new areas to increase forest cover.

questions.question_text: The 3Rs of environmental conservation are Reduce, Reuse, and _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The 3Rs are Reduce, Reuse, and Recycle. Recycle means processing used materials to create new products, reducing the need for raw materials and keeping waste out of landfills.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While repair, remove, and replace are useful words, the three Rs of environmental conservation are specifically Reduce, Reuse, and Recycle.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a renewable source of energy that does not cause air pollution?
questions.explanation_correct: Solar energy is renewable (the sun will keep shining) and clean (it does not produce any air pollution). Coal, petrol, and diesel are fossil fuels that produce smoke and carbon dioxide when burned, causing air pollution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Coal, petrol, and diesel are all fossil fuels that cause air pollution when burned. Solar energy is the only renewable and clean source listed, producing no harmful emissions.

questions.question_text: Why is it important to separate biodegradable and non-biodegradable waste?

options.text: So that biodegradable waste can be composted and non-biodegradable waste can be recycled
So both can be thrown in the river
So both can be burned together

questions.explanation_correct: Separating waste allows proper processing. Biodegradable waste (food scraps, leaves) can be composted to make useful manure. Non-biodegradable waste (plastic, metal, glass) can be sent for recycling. This reduces pollution and landfill waste.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Throwing waste in rivers or burning it causes pollution. Waste separation is very important because different types of waste need different treatment. Composting and recycling are far better than dumping or burning.

questions.question_text: Kiran's school has a 'green club' that plants trees, collects waste for recycling, and teaches students to save water and electricity. Which environmental practices are they following?
questions.explanation_correct: The green club practices afforestation (planting trees), recycling (collecting waste for recycling), and conservation (saving water and electricity, which is 'reduce'). They are following multiple environmental practices.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The club is doing much more than just one thing. They are planting trees (afforestation), recycling waste, and teaching conservation (reducing water and electricity use). These all come under environmental conservation.

questions.question_text: Which of the following actions would do the MOST to protect the environment?

options.text: One person using a cloth bag once
Everyone in a community working together to reduce waste, plant trees, and conserve resources
One factory cleaning its waste water

questions.explanation_correct: While every small action helps, the biggest impact comes when an entire community works together. If everyone reduces waste, plants trees, and conserves resources, the combined effect is much greater than any single action alone.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Individual actions are important, but community-wide efforts have the biggest impact. When everyone participates in reducing waste, planting trees, and conserving resources, the environmental benefits multiply enormously.
